summary: Yes about Dany having EXPERIENCE in RULING The whole BS about Jon being a perfect King He'd suck asses. He has no idea where to...
question: Yes about Dany having EXPERIENCE in RULING The whole BS about Jon being a perfect King He'd suck asses. He has no idea where to begin, doesnt like to do it and ppl would manipulate the shit out of him. Ned part II. He'd be perfect WITH dany ruling alongside him, but we know that makes TOO MUCH SENSE for happening. Anyway, Dany might be more ruthless and arrogant at times but shs GOOD,KNOWS the job, and she has a political mission (the wheel). Jon is a natural leader, but thats not enough
answer:
I hate the whole “he could temper her worst impulses” like literally shut the fuck up you trick ass insect.

Anyways, not to be super Jonerys on my jonerys got blog but yes. I think they’ve both from the very beginning have been set up to rule in some capacity. They were both forced into a position that neither really wanted. Daenerys was forced into the Dothraki culture and made Khaleesi and while Jon wasn’t literally sold into the Nights Watch, didn’t really have any other place to go and was eventually made Lord Commander. I just don’t understand having them both rule, having them both fight wars, free people, have all these great people surrounding them and teaching them (barisstan / jorah , aemon / jeor) and it NOT end up with them ruling SOMEHOW in SOME CAPACITY. It doesn’t make a slick of sense for them to have alllll this experience and alllll these people to guide them and it not lead to them ruling. They’ve already said that they would live together, what does that entail?? Marriage = ruling together.

Jon has said 4737473 times that he doesn’t want to rule, which I get, boi is tired and just wants to rest, so maybe he’ll just lowkey be on the back burner and only have to intervene when Daenerys needs it or they need both of them. IDK. Idk. But like I said. It’s just BAD WRITING and BAD STORYTELLING if they both have all this experience ruling and learning for it to just….. go no where?? Like??? What??

summary:
I think all this “spoilers” thing it getting out of hand.
I love spoilers and I’m the type of person that will read every...
body:
I think all this “spoilers” thing it getting out of hand.

I love spoilers and I’m the type of person that will read every spoilery thing bc it makes me even more excited but since the last episode and how bad it went people took advantage to post spoilers that I don’t think that they’re even true and have created drama and more drama when some actors don’t even know the real ending aka John Brandley (Sam)

The only spoilers I truly believe are the ones who most of the time come out the day the episode airs or when a image leaks meaning that the whole episode leaked somewhere.

We are now believing every spoiler thread that says is “100% confirmed” me included. So everyone is reading a bunch of spoilers most of them new ones and it’s getting out of control .Honestly we’re the one who are going to get mad by the end of this series.

This whole thing is giving so much anxiety jesus…

body:
or something close to it, do you think 2 episodes (of which one includes a fight Sansa is not even part of) is enough to explore pol!jon IF he exists ? let alone some jonsa masterplan? 

I’m beginning/fearing that there is no pol!jon and in that case I don’t think my Lady of Winterfell deserves season 7/8 Jon…. I don’t know, I am really confused and I honestly don’t understand why so much framing and foreshadowing if we end up with a rushed/ seemingly ga shocking end…..

summary: If What Happened to Dany had Happened to Jon
title: If What Happened to Dany had Happened to Jon
body:
Jon in Battle of the Bastards: Rushes in to save rickon putting himself in jeopardy and completely fucking up the entire plan. When he defeats ramsay he beats the ABSOLUTE shit out of him. 

Did anyone call him mad? He got killed for saving the lives of the wildings. Did he get backlash from fans? 

Dany in Battle of Winterfell: Rushes to save Jon putting herself in jeopardy (called useless), loses Jorah, cripples her army, has to fight her own baby. Only person who acknowledges and toasts Arya.

Dany at Dragon’s Bay: Saves slaves. SLAVES! Sets the throne aside for the greater good. This is the second time she has done that when she didnt even need to. She’s good at heart.  

Fans: MAD QUEEN! 

No matter what - Jon the dumb but just man is my king. 

Dan the somewhat smart, very impulsive, soft sometimes, just and kind is my queen. No further comments. 

it’s sad how it’s 2019 and we still see male/female characters differently.

summary: Hey! which episode of season 8 is worst, 3 or 4? Im going with 3 because while 4 was cringy, 3 was actually devastating for the...
question: Hey! which episode of season 8 is worst, 3 or 4? Im going with 3 because while 4 was cringy, 3 was actually devastating for the story arc overall.
answer:
A RIDICULE OF ICE AND FIRE: The On-Screen Fanfiction that tripped over itself 

I’m ready to break my incoherent rambles streak and put my thoughts into stone. I must warn you, if you are trying to stay positive, kindly scroll past this and possibly filter the tag #Debbie Downer

The show has been progressively worsening in the plot-driven creative decisions for a while now, but hasn’t been so blatantly apparent the general audience until this Season.

Tying up loose ends becomes harder when your rope is frayed. 

VIEWING GoT THROUGH CULTURAL LENSES: Race, Gender and Disability. But trust me it’s ~hIsToRicAlLy aCcuRatE~

Both Episode 3 and 4 have deeply problematic relationships with People of Color, namely Missandei, The Dothraki, and the indifference towards the xenophobia in the North and The Starks. People of color are disposable, and being “wary” of them is not only reasonable, but an expectation.

They also have had some of the most astounding sexism yet, and thats saying a lot for GoT. The story tries to address Daenerys being discredited entirely for her efforts, while simultaneously framing Dany as being irrational for not getting credit, so it becomes contradictory. The more shocking but is the framing of Sansa’s suffering as necessary experience points. That’s just wrong. And those are only the overt instances, but there are also the quiet implication that Arya cannot possibly be a lady or a love interest because she is just too badass (Badass in GoT being interchangeable with violent).

Also, I’m going to give the ableism an honorable mention because it’s a show-wide thing that continues to follow Bran, Tyrion, and possibly Mad!Targaryen disease. Yikes.

But these are just social commentaries on Game of Thrones. If you are D&D (white, straight men), and you don’t care about that, you should still be able to identify the structural problems in the writing:

- - Full social, literary, and cinematic commentary under the cut - -

THE LONG (short) NIGHT:  gotcha! Thrones have more relevance than the threat of human inhalation hehehe

Everyone who has followed my blog knows that I not only believed, but also rooted for Daenerys to be the one to end the Long Night. In fact, I thought they would take the book route of having her die for the living. On a magical level, it makes no sense for Dany to have dragons and Jon to return to life so they can further a political plot. They had a part to play on the Long Night, and they should have at least helped cause a chain of events that lead on to the (show only) Night King’s death. That said, I was actually very proud of Arya being the one to do the deed, and if it wasn’t Dany, I was thrilled it was her, because it uses her training for something better than revenge, but protection. Unfortunately, it was all very choppy. The Night King was too invincible for a satisfying death: There was no drop of Thanos’ blood, no wounded Sauron, only a cocky smile after Dany failed to burn him. Dany, Jon, and even Theon should have prepped the Night King for death, because it’s all about putting out differences aside for good. Not to mention there was no emotional stakes against the Night King. No personal sacrifice or outstanding humane bravery was necessary, only physical skill. There is nothing unrealistic about Arya being the hero, but it diminishes her heroic standpoint when the Night King is just another regular guy that can die from a stab. And in ONE episode!! Sure, the weapon was important, but if all was needed to kill the NK was Valyrian steel, then heck, Bronn might as well show up with a Valyrian scorpion, why not? The Long Night was not a battle of Humanity uniting against evil, but force 1 versus force 2. YES, there were consequences like Theon, Jorah, Lyanna, and Edd, but it wasn’t different than any other battle of strength. The magical, thematic, and emotional stakes of the Long Night were completely disregarded. It specially becomes apparent when the final villains are human, because it disregards that the entire point of the Long Night is humanity against the humane. 

AEGON VS. DAENERYS: Surprise! it’s a Sansa Plot! lolz gotcha again

EVEN in a scenario where betraying Daenerys and crowning Jon was the morally correct thing to do for Sansa and Varys (Tyrion?), it was not framed that way (as far as they know). Yes, Daenerys has been undeniably snappy, stubborn, and frustrating this season. But she has not given Sansa or Arya an INKLING of tangible proof to disregard her as a Queen. All the people she’s fought so far have been slavers, rapists, and soldiers, the latter one being Lannisters soldiers, the very ones Sansa had been imploring Jon to address. If Daenerys marches her armies North, she’s starving them, but if she doesn’t she’s a selfish bitch who doesn’t care about the North’s welfare. It makes Sansa seem unreasonable, and, well, petty. Why hate Dany? just cuz! They should have written Sansa to say something along the lines of “Daenerys hasn’t given me a personal reason to distrust her yet, but what about the Southern kings that come after her? will they keep the North safe? How will I know the North will stay out of Southern affairs generations after Daenerys? For these reasons a, b and c, I think the North should be independent.” etc etc etc. Arya could have said this too. Instead we got “We said we wouldn’t bow to anyone!” and “She’s not one of us”, which makes them both sound power hungry and xenophobic. Consier the fact that Sansa broke Jon’s trust for personal gain. Sansa does not seek to support her brother, but rather push him to do something he’ll probably resent her for. Show!Sansa doesn’t care about Jon or Jon’s wants. Consider that she doesn’t even trust Jon’s judgement, so it makes us think the only reason she wants him as King is so she can remain the most powerful person in the North. This is a Littlefinger move. This is a Cersei move. This is a huge disservice to the Starks. It also makes Varys seem like he only wants a ruler whom he can control.

CHARACTER CONSTANCY: New phone who dis??

Book Sansa Stark:

“Help [Lancel],” Sansa commanded two of the serving men. One just looked at her and ran, flagon and all… .Together, Sansa and the serving man got the wounded knight back on his feet. “Take him to Maester Frenken.” Lancel was one of them, yet somehow she still could not bring herself to wish him dead. I am soft and weak and stupid, just as Joffrey says. I should be killing him, not helping him.

Sansa could not believe she had spoken. Was she mad? To tell [Joffrey] no in front of half the court? She hadn’t meant to say anything, only … Ser Dontos was drunk and silly and useless, but he meant no harm.

A good heart. I have a good heart. Hysterical laughter rose up her gullet, but Sansa choked it back down. The bells were ringing, slow and mournful. Ringing, ringing, ringing. They had rung for King Robert the same way. Joffrey was dead, he was dead, he was dead, dead, dead. Why was she crying, when she wanted to dance? Were they tears of joy?

What was it that Septa Mordane used to tell her? A lady’s armor is courtesy, that was it. She donned her armor

Yet … despite her constant and consistent book compassion, the only thing the show seems constant is that Sansa has learned compassion is naive, courtesy is stupid, suffering is a necessity to thrive, and manipulation is the only way you can survive.  

Book Arya Stark:

Sansa knew all about the sorts of people Arya liked to talk to: squires and grooms and serving girls, old men and naked children, rough-spoken freeriders of uncertain birth. Arya would make friends with anybody.

Arya’s place was Winterfell, only Winterfell was gone. When the snows fall and the white winds blow, the lone wolf dies, but the pack survives.

She would make much better time on her own, Arya knew, but she could not leave them. They were her pack, her friends, the only living friends that remained to her, and if not for her they would still be safe at Harrenhal, Gendry sweating at his forge and Hot Pie in the kitchens. 

[Arya] had made friends along the wharves; porters and mummers, ropemakers and sailmenders, taverners, brewers and bakers and beggars and whores. They […] told her true tales of Braavos and lies about their lives, and laughed at the way she talked when she tried to speak Braavosi.

Arya was friends to anyone and everyone. She is open minded, curious and well traveled. She was not willing to leave “her pack” when they were only orphans she knew for a few months (Gendry being one of them) let alone her family. Her place was Winterfell. So why would Arya refer to Daenerys as an outsider? Why would Arya go out of her way to avoid social events and talking to people? Why would Arya leave her loved ones and her home without so much as a goodbye? Because the plot needs her to.

Book Samwell Tarly (oh yes him too!) 

Sam’s head bobbed up and down with every step that Small Paul took. “Stop it,” he muttered, “put me down, I’m not a baby. I’m a man of the Night’s Watch.” He sobbed. “Just let me die.”

It amazes me that the very same show that made Sam progress from being unable to walk any longer for his life, to being able to protect Gilly and stand up for himself, revert back into the young boy who fell down crying in battle. Sam! who wanted to live his life being a hero rather than reading of them. Grenn, Pyp, and Edd put their lives on the line to help Sam grow and overcome this, and he did! But suddenly he forgot how to fight for his life, and Edd had to die as a consequence. Not only that, but Sam did not wake up after Edd’s death, but rather continued to sob helplessly and swatting away wights. Did this have a consequence? NAH! Plot armor needs him for … to protect Gilly again, even though he can’t protect himself. 

Book Jon Snow: 

Fat and awkward and frightened he might be, but Samwell Tarly was no fool. One night he visited Jon in his cell. “I don’t know what you did,” he said, “but I know you did it.” He looked away shyly. “I’ve never had a friend before.”

“We’re not friends,” Jon said. He put a hand on Sam’s broad shoulder. “We’re brothers.”

Ghost ran with them for a time and then vanished among the trees. Without the direwolf, Jon felt almost naked.

Ghost was with him, he knew that much. The silent presence of the direwolf gave him comfort. 

Jon wondered where Ghost was now. Had he gone to Castle Black, or was he was running with some wolfpack in the woods? He had no sense of the direwolf, not even in his dreams. It made him feel as if part of himself had been cut off. Even with Ygritte sleeping beside him, he felt alone. He did not want to die alone.

Book Jon has always been very different than show Jon. Book Jon has a lot of unresolved self-hatred, but he is also more arrogant, with ambition and hunger to prove himself. Show Jon is an embodiment of “Ambition is bad and only those who abhor power are worthy”, which strays far from truth. But the direction of this season also makes him disregard Sam’s life, which I can understand for the need of killing the Night King, but come on at least show a bit of remorse on Sam here. But Ghost?? There is nothing in show or book canon, EVEN PLOT-DRIVEN REASONING, to neglect Ghost. Couldn’t you just have a single shot of Ghost and Jon in the end, and pretend he was with Jon all along like the cheap ass s5-s6 did? What about his place with the Starks? What does Jon want exactly? to marry Daenerys? to stay home with his sisters? does he really want to be North with Tormund more than anything? if not, why say it? And are we really disregarding 7 Seasons and 5 books of bastard inner struggle for him not to come to terms with his heritage? Really, it seems that the biggest topic this season “SHOULD JON BE KING?” involves EVERYONE except Jon himself.

Book Daenerys Targaryen: 

“Only death may pay for life.“

“Death?” Dany wrapped her arms around herself protectively, rocked back and forth on her heels. “My death?” She told herself she would die for him, if she must. She was the blood of the dragon, she would not be afraid.

Why do the gods make kings and queens, if not to protect the ones who can’t protect themselves?“

This one is very complex, with controversies left and right, but I’m about to make points that not even the most ardent Dany haters could not refute. Bear with me.

I … love Daenerys. More than any other character. Ever. 

That said, I acknowledge she will go through a dark inner struggle in the books and that she is more morally ambiguous than your average protagonist. As a minority, I understand she has white savior tropes in her story (though severely more pronounced in the show than books). I reject the notion that Daenerys, or anyone, should sit the Iron throne. And I admit that I believe Dany will die sacrificing herself in the books. 

Not to mention, leaving the big villains of the series to be Cersei and Dany is very redundant after we faced the end of the world with the Night King. Humanity needs to unite or die…..until they don’t. Remember, this is the Game of Thrones, so all we do here is #ForTheThrone. 

But let’s assume the Mad Queen theories were right (and not sexist) all along. Let’s assume that there is nothing problematic about introducing an army of people of color led by a mad woman who rape and raid and cause unnecessary destruction (that she so vocally avoided through every city take over yet). Let’s assume that disposing of the Dothraki, Unsullied, and closest black friend was very necessary to emphasize how unstable Daenerys is. Let’s assume that Daenerys’ only motivation to free slaves, rescue Jon, and save the North was entirely for personal gain. Where is the dramatic build up?

So now we have a scenario in which Daenerys has done good deeds, but only because she has evil, selfish motives. Very plausible for many of you already.

And yet … what has Dany done to be considered evil, at this point (8.04) of the story? Once again I ask, what tangible proof does the story provide that Daenerys Targaryen will go at any lengths to gain power? 

The people she’s fought? Slavers, rapists, and soldiers who attacked her first.

The people she wants to fight? Cersei Lannister, the same person Sansa and Tyrion have been going on and on and on about wanting to dethrone. 

The fact that she keeps reprimanding her advisors for giving her bad advice, even though … all their advice has failed?

The fact that she resents being discredited and distrusted for all her efforts, even though she has been?

The only thing that hints to Mad Dany is her heritage, something that she has no control over. And even here, shouldn’t we sympathize with that? Is the show saying Dany is not responsible of her actions because of her inherent madness, or will they hold her accountable for ignoring her mental state (???)

If I was a show writer, and I wanted to wrap up a coherent Mad!Dany Plot, ASSUMING it’s not problematic in all levels and ASSUMING it’s what was meant to happen all along, I would have needed to introduce actions that make her sanity questionable long ago (not just morally ambiguous choices, actual insane choices), and build up that tension over and over and over, maybe out of the earshot of other characters, until the tension snaps and she does something unforgivable. 

The vocal criticism over so many fans and so many media outlets over Dany’s arc in the show is not because we were all, the millions and millions of us, too stupid to see it coming, but because there was an absolute lack of buildup for it.

If they wanted any sweetness in bittersweet, they could have at the very least framed Sansa’s betrayal of Jon’s trust as a necessary moral act. At least a small portion of Sansa fans would have said “oh she had to do to the hard thing because it was the right thing.” But as I said above, it’s not that way. Jaime attacked Ned and fought Robb but Sansa trusts Brienne’s word; why can’t she trust Jon’s? Is she threatened by the lack of power, or can she justify her anger? This makes the audience dislike both Dany and Sansa, feel indifference to Arya, and leave out Jon from his very own plotline. 

It’s just as Tyrion said "You seem determined to dislike [Dany]”. And so does she show itself. The story has been going out of their way to make Dany dislikable. Snappy, stubborn, cold, petty. They want you to think “Damn, what a bitch”, so you can side with Sansa. And some try, but it’s simply too bitter on all sides to side with anyone. Tyrion is too torn to side with anyone, because he’s too compassionate, but the way it’s headed, it seems compassion is a weakness in this Game of Thrones. You’d rather stop watching the show that find out what happens next.

That’s not even mentioning the stories of Brienne, Cersei, Euron, the Hound, Gendry, Davos, and Jaime. What!! The!! Heck!! 

Where is the hope for the future? Where is the unity? Where is the fight against darkness? Not the actual physical fight, but the humane struggle for good? Where is the “sweet” from the bittersweet? Just exactly who are we supposed to root for? 

The show can’t seem to answer these questions, and neither can we. 

…

but hey,

Make some great memes out of it and send them my way please :)
answer_abstract:
A RIDICULE OF ICE AND FIRE: The On-Screen Fanfiction that tripped over itself 

I’m ready to break my incoherent rambles streak and put my thoughts into stone. I must warn you, if you are trying to stay positive, kindly scroll past this and possibly filter the tag #Debbie Downer

The show has been progressively worsening in the plot-driven creative decisions for a while now, but hasn’t been so blatantly apparent the general audience until this Season.

Tying up loose ends becomes harder when your rope is frayed. 

VIEWING GoT THROUGH CULTURAL LENSES: Race, Gender and Disability. But trust me it’s ~hIsToRicAlLy aCcuRatE~

Both Episode 3 and 4 have deeply problematic relationships with People of Color, namely Missandei, The Dothraki, and the indifference towards the xenophobia in the North and The Starks. People of color are disposable, and being “wary” of them is not only reasonable, but an expectation.

They also have had some of the most astounding sexism yet, and thats saying a lot for GoT. The story tries to address Daenerys being discredited entirely for her efforts, while simultaneously framing Dany as being irrational for not getting credit, so it becomes contradictory. The more shocking but is the framing of Sansa’s suffering as necessary experience points. That’s just wrong. And those are only the overt instances, but there are also the quiet implication that Arya cannot possibly be a lady or a love interest because she is just too badass (Badass in GoT being interchangeable with violent).

Also, I’m going to give the ableism an honorable mention because it’s a show-wide thing that continues to follow Bran, Tyrion, and possibly Mad!Targaryen disease. Yikes.

But these are just social commentaries on Game of Thrones. If you are D&D (white, straight men), and you don’t care about that, you should still be able to identify the structural problems in the writing:

- - Full social, literary, and cinematic commentary under the cut - -

THE LONG (short) NIGHT:  gotcha! Thrones have more relevance than the threat of human inhalation hehehe

Everyone who has followed my blog knows that I not only believed, but also rooted for Daenerys to be the one to end the Long Night. In fact, I thought they would take the book route of having her die for the living. On a magical level, it makes no sense for Dany to have dragons and Jon to return to life so they can further a political plot. They had a part to play on the Long Night, and they should have at least helped cause a chain of events that lead on to the (show only) Night King’s death. That said, I was actually very proud of Arya being the one to do the deed, and if it wasn’t Dany, I was thrilled it was her, because it uses her training for something better than revenge, but protection. Unfortunately, it was all very choppy. The Night King was too invincible for a satisfying death: There was no drop of Thanos’ blood, no wounded Sauron, only a cocky smile after Dany failed to burn him. Dany, Jon, and even Theon should have prepped the Night King for death, because it’s all about putting out differences aside for good. Not to mention there was no emotional stakes against the Night King. No personal sacrifice or outstanding humane bravery was necessary, only physical skill. There is nothing unrealistic about Arya being the hero, but it diminishes her heroic standpoint when the Night King is just another regular guy that can die from a stab. And in ONE episode!! Sure, the weapon was important, but if all was needed to kill the NK was Valyrian steel, then heck, Bronn might as well show up with a Valyrian scorpion, why not? The Long Night was not a battle of Humanity uniting against evil, but force 1 versus force 2. YES, there were consequences like Theon, Jorah, Lyanna, and Edd, but it wasn’t different than any other battle of strength. The magical, thematic, and emotional stakes of the Long Night were completely disregarded. It specially becomes apparent when the final villains are human, because it disregards that the entire point of the Long Night is humanity against the humane. 

AEGON VS. DAENERYS: Surprise! it’s a Sansa Plot! lolz gotcha again

EVEN in a scenario where betraying Daenerys and crowning Jon was the morally correct thing to do for Sansa and Varys (Tyrion?), it was not framed that way (as far as they know). Yes, Daenerys has been undeniably snappy, stubborn, and frustrating this season. But she has not given Sansa or Arya an INKLING of tangible proof to disregard her as a Queen. All the people she’s fought so far have been slavers, rapists, and soldiers, the latter one being Lannisters soldiers, the very ones Sansa had been imploring Jon to address. If Daenerys marches her armies North, she’s starving them, but if she doesn’t she’s a selfish bitch who doesn’t care about the North’s welfare. It makes Sansa seem unreasonable, and, well, petty. Why hate Dany? just cuz! They should have written Sansa to say something along the lines of “Daenerys hasn’t given me a personal reason to distrust her yet, but what about the Southern kings that come after her? will they keep the North safe? How will I know the North will stay out of Southern affairs generations after Daenerys? For these reasons a, b and c, I think the North should be independent.” etc etc etc. Arya could have said this too. Instead we got “We said we wouldn’t bow to anyone!” and “She’s not one of us”, which makes them both sound power hungry and xenophobic. Consier the fact that Sansa broke Jon’s trust for personal gain. Sansa does not seek to support her brother, but rather push him to do something he’ll probably resent her for. Show!Sansa doesn’t care about Jon or Jon’s wants. Consider that she doesn’t even trust Jon’s judgement, so it makes us think the only reason she wants him as King is so she can remain the most powerful person in the North. This is a Littlefinger move. This is a Cersei move. This is a huge disservice to the Starks. It also makes Varys seem like he only wants a ruler whom he can control.

CHARACTER CONSTANCY: New phone who dis??

Book Sansa Stark:

“Help [Lancel],” Sansa commanded two of the serving men. One just looked at her and ran, flagon and all… .Together, Sansa and the serving man got the wounded knight back on his feet. “Take him to Maester Frenken.” Lancel was one of them, yet somehow she still could not bring herself to wish him dead. I am soft and weak and stupid, just as Joffrey says. I should be killing him, not helping him.

Sansa could not believe she had spoken. Was she mad? To tell [Joffrey] no in front of half the court? She hadn’t meant to say anything, only … Ser Dontos was drunk and silly and useless, but he meant no harm.

A good heart. I have a good heart. Hysterical laughter rose up her gullet, but Sansa choked it back down. The bells were ringing, slow and mournful. Ringing, ringing, ringing. They had rung for King Robert the same way. Joffrey was dead, he was dead, he was dead, dead, dead. Why was she crying, when she wanted to dance? Were they tears of joy?

What was it that Septa Mordane used to tell her? A lady’s armor is courtesy, that was it. She donned her armor

Yet … despite her constant and consistent book compassion, the only thing the show seems constant is that Sansa has learned compassion is naive, courtesy is stupid, suffering is a necessity to thrive, and manipulation is the only way you can survive.  

Book Arya Stark:

Sansa knew all about the sorts of people Arya liked to talk to: squires and grooms and serving girls, old men and naked children, rough-spoken freeriders of uncertain birth. Arya would make friends with anybody.

Arya’s place was Winterfell, only Winterfell was gone. When the snows fall and the white winds blow, the lone wolf dies, but the pack survives.

She would make much better time on her own, Arya knew, but she could not leave them. They were her pack, her friends, the only living friends that remained to her, and if not for her they would still be safe at Harrenhal, Gendry sweating at his forge and Hot Pie in the kitchens. 

[Arya] had made friends along the wharves; porters and mummers, ropemakers and sailmenders, taverners, brewers and bakers and beggars and whores. They […] told her true tales of Braavos and lies about their lives, and laughed at the way she talked when she tried to speak Braavosi.

Arya was friends to anyone and everyone. She is open minded, curious and well traveled. She was not willing to leave “her pack” when they were only orphans she knew for a few months (Gendry being one of them) let alone her family. Her place was Winterfell. So why would Arya refer to Daenerys as an outsider? Why would Arya go out of her way to avoid social events and talking to people? Why would Arya leave her loved ones and her home without so much as a goodbye? Because the plot needs her to.

Book Samwell Tarly (oh yes him too!) 

Sam’s head bobbed up and down with every step that Small Paul took. “Stop it,” he muttered, “put me down, I’m not a baby. I’m a man of the Night’s Watch.” He sobbed. “Just let me die.”

It amazes me that the very same show that made Sam progress from being unable to walk any longer for his life, to being able to protect Gilly and stand up for himself, revert back into the young boy who fell down crying in battle. Sam! who wanted to live his life being a hero rather than reading of them. Grenn, Pyp, and Edd put their lives on the line to help Sam grow and overcome this, and he did! But suddenly he forgot how to fight for his life, and Edd had to die as a consequence. Not only that, but Sam did not wake up after Edd’s death, but rather continued to sob helplessly and swatting away wights. Did this have a consequence? NAH! Plot armor needs him for … to protect Gilly again, even though he can’t protect himself. 

Book Jon Snow: 

Fat and awkward and frightened he might be, but Samwell Tarly was no fool. One night he visited Jon in his cell. “I don’t know what you did,” he said, “but I know you did it.” He looked away shyly. “I’ve never had a friend before.”

“We’re not friends,” Jon said. He put a hand on Sam’s broad shoulder. “We’re brothers.”

Ghost ran with them for a time and then vanished among the trees. Without the direwolf, Jon felt almost naked.

Ghost was with him, he knew that much. The silent presence of the direwolf gave him comfort. 

Jon wondered where Ghost was now. Had he gone to Castle Black, or was he was running with some wolfpack in the woods? He had no sense of the direwolf, not even in his dreams. It made him feel as if part of himself had been cut off. Even with Ygritte sleeping beside him, he felt alone. He did not want to die alone.

Really, it seems that the biggest topic this season “SHOULD JON BE KING?” involves EVERYONE except Jon himself.

“Only death may pay for life.“

“Death?” Dany wrapped her arms around herself protectively, rocked back and forth on her heels. “My death?” She told herself she would die for him, if she must. She was the blood of the dragon, she would not be afraid.

This is a Littlefinger move. This is a Cersei move. This is a huge disservice to the Starks. It also makes Varys seem like he only wants a ruler whom he can control.

CHARACTER CONSTANCY: New phone who dis??

Book Sansa Stark:

“Help [Lancel],” Sansa commanded two of the serving men. One just looked at her and ran, flagon and all… .Together, Sansa and the serving man got the wounded knight back on his feet. “Take him to Maester Frenken.” Lancel was one of them, yet somehow she still could not bring herself to wish him dead. I am soft and weak and stupid, just as Joffrey says. I should be killing him, not helping him.

Sansa could not believe she had spoken. Was she mad? To tell [Joffrey] no in front of half the court? She hadn’t meant to say anything, only … Ser Dontos was drunk and silly and useless, but he meant no harm.

A good heart. I have a good heart. Hysterical laughter rose up her gullet, but Sansa choked it back down. The bells were ringing, slow and mournful. Ringing, ringing, ringing. They had rung for King Robert the same way. Joffrey was dead, he was dead, he was dead, dead, dead. Why was she crying, when she wanted to dance? Were they tears of joy?

What was it that Septa Mordane used to tell her? A lady’s armor is courtesy, that was it. She donned her armor

Yet … despite her constant and consistent book compassion, the only thing the show seems constant is that Sansa has learned compassion is naive, courtesy is stupid, suffering is a necessity to thrive, and manipulation is the only way you can survive.  

Book Arya Stark:

Sansa knew all about the sorts of people Arya liked to talk to: squires and grooms and serving girls, old men and naked children, rough-spoken freeriders of uncertain birth. Arya would make friends with anybody.

Arya’s place was Winterfell, only Winterfell was gone. When the snows fall and the white winds blow, the lone wolf dies, but the pack survives.

She would make much better time on her own, Arya knew, but she could not leave them. They were her pack, her friends, the only living friends that remained to her, and if not for her they would still be safe at Harrenhal, Gendry sweating at his forge and Hot Pie in the kitchens. 

[Arya] had made friends along the wharves; porters and mummers, ropemakers and sailmenders, taverners, brewers and bakers and beggars and whores. They […] told her true tales of Braavos and lies about their lives, and laughed at the way she talked when she tried to speak Braavosi.

Arya was friends to anyone and everyone. She is open minded, curious and well traveled. She was not willing to leave “her pack” when they were only orphans she knew for a few months (Gendry being one of them) let alone her family. Her place was Winterfell. So why would Arya refer to Daenerys as an outsider? Why would Arya go out of her way to avoid social events and talking to people? Why would Arya leave her loved ones and her home without so much as a goodbye? Because the plot needs her to.

Book Samwell Tarly (oh yes him too!) 

Sam’s head bobbed up and down with every step that Small Paul took. “Stop it,” he muttered, “put me down, I’m not a baby. I’m a man of the Night’s Watch.” He sobbed. “Just let me die.”

It amazes me that the very same show that made Sam progress from being unable to walk any longer for his life, to being able to protect Gilly and stand up for himself, revert back into the young boy who fell down crying in battle. Sam! who wanted to live his life being a hero rather than reading of them. Grenn, Pyp, and Edd put their lives on the line to help Sam grow and overcome this, and he did! But suddenly he forgot how to fight for his life, and Edd had to die as a consequence. Not only that, but Sam did not wake up after Edd’s death, but rather continued to sob helplessly and swatting away wights. Did this have a consequence? NAH! Plot armor needs him for … to protect Gilly again, even though he can’t protect himself. 

Book Jon Snow: 

Fat and awkward and frightened he might be, but Samwell Tarly was no fool. One night he visited Jon in his cell. “I don’t know what you did,” he said, “but I know you did it.” He looked away shyly. “I’ve never had a friend before.”

“We’re not friends,” Jon said. He put a hand on Sam’s broad shoulder. “We’re brothers.”

Ghost ran with them for a time and then vanished among the trees. Without the direwolf, Jon felt almost naked.

Ghost was with him, he knew that much. The silent presence of the direwolf gave him comfort. 

Jon wondered where Ghost was now. Had he gone to Castle Black, or was he was running with some wolfpack in the woods? He had no sense of the direwolf, not even in his dreams. It made him feel as if part of himself had been cut off. Even with Ygritte sleeping beside him, he felt alone. He did not want to die alone.

Book Jon has always been very different than show Jon. Book Jon has a lot of unresolved self-hatred, but he is also more arrogant, with ambition and hunger to prove himself. Show Jon is an embodiment of “Ambition is bad and only those who abhor power are worthy”, which strays far from truth. But the direction of this season also makes him disregard Sam’s life, which I can understand for the need of killing the Night King, but come on at least show a bit of remorse on Sam here. But Ghost?? There is nothing in show or book canon, EVEN PLOT-DRIVEN REASONING, to neglect Ghost. Couldn’t you just have a single shot of Ghost and Jon in the end, and pretend he was with Jon all along like the cheap ass s5-s6 did? What about his place with the Starks? What does Jon want exactly? to marry Daenerys? to stay home with his sisters? does he really want to be North with Tormund more than anything? if not, why say it? And are we really disregarding 7 Seasons and 5 books of bastard inner struggle for him not to come to terms with his heritage? Really, it seems that the biggest topic this season “SHOULD JON BE KING?” involves EVERYONE except Jon himself.

Book Daenerys Targaryen: 

“Only death may pay for life.“

“Death?” Dany wrapped her arms around herself protectively, rocked back and forth on her heels. “My death?” She told herself she would die for him, if she must. She was the blood of the dragon, she would not be afraid.

Why do the gods make kings and queens, if not to protect the ones who can’t protect themselves?“

This one is very complex, with controversies left and right, but I’m about to make points that not even the most ardent Dany haters could not refute. Bear with me.

I … love Daenerys. More than any other character. Ever. 

That said, I acknowledge she will go through a dark inner struggle in the books and that she is more morally ambiguous than your average protagonist. As a minority, I understand she has white savior tropes in her story (though severely more pronounced in the show than books). I reject the notion that Daenerys, or anyone, should sit the Iron throne. And I admit that I believe Dany will die sacrificing herself in the books. 

Not to mention, leaving the big villains of the series to be Cersei and Dany is very redundant after we faced the end of the world with the Night King. Humanity needs to unite or die…..until they don’t. Remember, this is the Game of Thrones, so all we do here is #ForTheThrone. 

But let’s assume the Mad Queen theories were right (and not sexist) all along. Let’s assume that there is nothing problematic about introducing an army of people of color led by a mad woman who rape and raid and cause unnecessary destruction (that she so vocally avoided through every city take over yet). Let’s assume that disposing of the Dothraki, Unsullied, and closest black friend was very necessary to emphasize how unstable Daenerys is. Let’s assume that Daenerys’ only motivation to free slaves, rescue Jon, and save the North was entirely for personal gain. Where is the dramatic build up?

So now we have a scenario in which Daenerys has done good deeds, but only because she has evil, selfish motives. Very plausible for many of you already.

And yet … what has Dany done to be considered evil, at this point (8.04) of the story? Once again I ask, what tangible proof does the story provide that Daenerys Targaryen will go at any lengths to gain power? 

The people she’s fought? Slavers, rapists, and soldiers who attacked her first.

The people she wants to fight? Cersei Lannister, the same person Sansa and Tyrion have been going on and on and on about wanting to dethrone. 

The fact that she keeps reprimanding her advisors for giving her bad advice, even though … all their advice has failed?

The fact that she resents being discredited and distrusted for all her efforts, even though she has been?

The only thing that hints to Mad Dany is her heritage, something that she has no control over. And even here, shouldn’t we sympathize with that? Is the show saying Dany is not responsible of her actions because of her inherent madness, or will they hold her accountable for ignoring her mental state (???)

If I was a show writer, and I wanted to wrap up a coherent Mad!Dany Plot, ASSUMING it’s not problematic in all levels and ASSUMING it’s what was meant to happen all along, I would have needed to introduce actions that make her sanity questionable long ago (not just morally ambiguous choices, actual insane choices), and build up that tension over and over and over, maybe out of the earshot of other characters, until the tension snaps and she does something unforgivable. 

The vocal criticism over so many fans and so many media outlets over Dany’s arc in the show is not because we were all, the millions and millions of us, too stupid to see it coming, but because there was an absolute lack of buildup for it.

If they wanted any sweetness in bittersweet, they could have at the very least framed Sansa’s betrayal of Jon’s trust as a necessary moral act. At least a small portion of Sansa fans would have said “oh she had to do to the hard thing because it was the right thing.” But as I said above, it’s not that way. Jaime attacked Ned and fought Robb but Sansa trusts Brienne’s word; why can’t she trust Jon’s? Is she threatened by the lack of power, or can she justify her anger? This makes the audience dislike both Dany and Sansa, feel indifference to Arya, and leave out Jon from his very own plotline. 

It’s just as Tyrion said "You seem determined to dislike [Dany]”. And so does she show itself. The story has been going out of their way to make Dany dislikable. Snappy, stubborn, cold, petty. They want you to think “Damn, what a bitch”, so you can side with Sansa. And some try, but it’s simply too bitter on all sides to side with anyone. Tyrion is too torn to side with anyone, because he’s too compassionate, but the way it’s headed, it seems compassion is a weakness in this Game of Thrones. You’d rather stop watching the show that find out what happens next.

That’s not even mentioning the stories of Brienne, Cersei, Euron, the Hound, Gendry, Davos, and Jaime. What!! The!! Heck!! 

Where is the hope for the future? Where is the unity? Where is the fight against darkness? Not the actual physical fight, but the humane struggle for good? Where is the “sweet” from the bittersweet? Just exactly who are we supposed to root for? 

The show can’t seem to answer these questions, and neither can we. 

…

but hey,

Make some great memes out of it and send them my way please :)
trail.content:
A RIDICULE OF ICE AND FIRE: The On-Screen Fanfiction that tripped over itself 

I’m ready to break my incoherent rambles streak and put my thoughts into stone. I must warn you, if you are trying to stay positive, kindly scroll past this and possibly filter the tag #Debbie Downer

The show has been progressively worsening in the plot-driven creative decisions for a while now, but hasn’t been so blatantly apparent the general audience until this Season.

Tying up loose ends becomes harder when your rope is frayed. 

VIEWING GoT THROUGH CULTURAL LENSES: Race, Gender and Disability. But trust me it’s ~hIsToRicAlLy aCcuRatE~

Both Episode 3 and 4 have deeply problematic relationships with People of Color, namely Missandei, The Dothraki, and the indifference towards the xenophobia in the North and The Starks. People of color are disposable, and being “wary” of them is not only reasonable, but an expectation.

They also have had some of the most astounding sexism yet, and thats saying a lot for GoT. The story tries to address Daenerys being discredited entirely for her efforts, while simultaneously framing Dany as being irrational for not getting credit, so it becomes contradictory. The more shocking but is the framing of Sansa’s suffering as necessary experience points. That’s just wrong. And those are only the overt instances, but there are also the quiet implication that Arya cannot possibly be a lady or a love interest because she is just too badass (Badass in GoT being interchangeable with violent).

Also, I’m going to give the ableism an honorable mention because it’s a show-wide thing that continues to follow Bran, Tyrion, and possibly Mad!Targaryen disease. Yikes.

But these are just social commentaries on Game of Thrones. If you are D&D (white, straight men), and you don’t care about that, you should still be able to identify the structural problems in the writing:

- - Full social, literary, and cinematic commentary under the cut - -

THE LONG (short) NIGHT:  gotcha! Thrones have more relevance than the threat of human inhalation hehehe

Everyone who has followed my blog knows that I not only believed, but also rooted for Daenerys to be the one to end the Long Night. In fact, I thought they would take the book route of having her die for the living. On a magical level, it makes no sense for Dany to have dragons and Jon to return to life so they can further a political plot. They had a part to play on the Long Night, and they should have at least helped cause a chain of events that lead on to the (show only) Night King’s death. That said, I was actually very proud of Arya being the one to do the deed, and if it wasn’t Dany, I was thrilled it was her, because it uses her training for something better than revenge, but protection. Unfortunately, it was all very choppy. The Night King was too invincible for a satisfying death: There was no drop of Thanos’ blood, no wounded Sauron, only a cocky smile after Dany failed to burn him. Dany, Jon, and even Theon should have prepped the Night King for death, because it’s all about putting out differences aside for good. Not to mention there was no emotional stakes against the Night King. No personal sacrifice or outstanding humane bravery was necessary, only physical skill. There is nothing unrealistic about Arya being the hero, but it diminishes her heroic standpoint when the Night King is just another regular guy that can die from a stab. And in ONE episode!! Sure, the weapon was important, but if all was needed to kill the NK was Valyrian steel, then heck, Bronn might as well show up with a Valyrian scorpion, why not? The Long Night was not a battle of Humanity uniting against evil, but force 1 versus force 2. YES, there were consequences like Theon, Jorah, Lyanna, and Edd, but it wasn’t different than any other battle of strength. The magical, thematic, and emotional stakes of the Long Night were completely disregarded. It specially becomes apparent when the final villains are human, because it disregards that the entire point of the Long Night is humanity against the humane. 

AEGON VS. DAENERYS: Surprise! it’s a Sansa Plot! lolz gotcha again

EVEN in a scenario where betraying Daenerys and crowning Jon was the morally correct thing to do for Sansa and Varys (Tyrion?), it was not framed that way (as far as they know). Yes, Daenerys has been undeniably snappy, stubborn, and frustrating this season. But she has not given Sansa or Arya an INKLING of tangible proof to disregard her as a Queen. All the people she’s fought so far have been slavers, rapists, and soldiers, the latter one being Lannisters soldiers, the very ones Sansa had been imploring Jon to address. If Daenerys marches her armies North, she’s starving them, but if she doesn’t she’s a selfish bitch who doesn’t care about the North’s welfare. It makes Sansa seem unreasonable, and, well, petty. Why hate Dany? just cuz! They should have written Sansa to say something along the lines of “Daenerys hasn’t given me a personal reason to distrust her yet, but what about the Southern kings that come after her? will they keep the North safe? How will I know the North will stay out of Southern affairs generations after Daenerys? For these reasons a, b and c, I think the North should be independent.” etc etc etc. Arya could have said this too. Instead we got “We said we wouldn’t bow to anyone!” and “She’s not one of us”, which makes them both sound power hungry and xenophobic. Consier the fact that Sansa broke Jon’s trust for personal gain. Sansa does not seek to support her brother, but rather push him to do something he’ll probably resent her for. Show!Sansa doesn’t care about Jon or Jon’s wants. Consider that she doesn’t even trust Jon’s judgement, so it makes us think the only reason she wants him as King is so she can remain the most powerful person in the North. This is a Littlefinger move. This is a Cersei move. This is a huge disservice to the Starks. It also makes Varys seem like he only wants a ruler whom he can control.

summary: "Since the direwolves are kind of CG creations, we felt it best to keep it as simple as possible," Nutter told the Huffington...
caption:
“Since the direwolves are kind of CG creations, we felt it best to keep it as simple as possible,” Nutter told the Huffington Post. When the New York Times asked Nutter if it was a “CGI issue” that restricted the pat we all wanted to see, Nutter responded, “Very much so.”

I just kept remembering the great scene from The Jungle Book and how great it would have been for Jon and Ghost to have a moment like that. So I did a bit of photoshopping.

summary: You know what i really dont get about d&d going for the “mad queen daenerys” theory? Everything, literally everything, up until...
body: You know what i really dont get about d&d going for the “mad queen daenerys” theory? Everything, literally everything, up until early season 8 was lining up for Dany and Jon ruling together. They had parallel journeys about coming into their own and becoming leaders and they eventually got together. Fuck.. they spent half of season 7 hinting at Dany getting pregnant, in the first episode of this goddamned season they had other characters suggesting that they’d get married. And then after seasons of build up for these two characters meeting, after establishing a romance and suggesting that they’d even have a child, these stupid ass showrunners/writers turn on their heels and just go “nah it would be MUCH BETTER if Dany just went mad and Jon had to kill her”. And I really cant wrap my head around the fact that theyre throwing out of the window a cliche but fulfilling ending that would have left most fans in peace with it for yet another Edgy Twist™️ that actually doesn’t make any sense.

summary: "It's cold."  Satin stood with his hands tucked into his armpits under his cloak. His cheeks were bright red.Jon made himself...
caption:
“It’s cold." 

Satin stood with his hands tucked into his armpits under his cloak. His cheeks were bright red.Jon made himself smile. 

"The Frostfangs are cold. This is a brisk autumn day." 

Not a personal ship of mine but 

Jon never loses an opportunity to remind us that Satin is pretty, and that being pretty is not his only good quality. 

[jeyne&theon]

[jaime&brienne]

[arya&gendry]

[sansa&sandor]

[jon&ygritte / jon&val]

[sam&gilly]

this chap is full of feels and smut and the Jorah tribute that at the time of writing we didn’t know we would need
the fandom that slays together stays together
summary:
~*~*~
He’d forgotten to close the blinds the night before, something overlooked in the aftermath of the fire, forgotten in his...
body:
Written in the Scars of This Heart - a snippet


~*~*~

He’d forgotten to close the blinds the night before, something overlooked in the aftermath of the fire, forgotten in his hurry to meet Daenerys, and definitely not on his mind at the end of his night. The brightness was creeping in, making him aware of the dull pounding of a headache, courtesy of rum, his eyelids feeling like sandpaper over his eyes.


But, all of that was forgotten, even the warmth of the sun after the summer storm, because there was a greater warmth curled into him. Soft snores tickled his ears, a slim leg tucked possessively over his, his right arm numb under her slight weight.


Gods, it had seemed like such a good idea the night before, scooping her up in his arms, the rain drenching them both as he carried her inside, her face tucked into his shoulder. He hadn’t been able to bring himself to put her into her nest on the floor— her bed still off limits— so he had done the only thing he could and tucked her into his bed.


It had seemed like a brilliant idea at the time, and since he was a grown arsed man who could control his impulses and urges, he had crawled into the covers on his side, not sure if the spinning world was from the alcohol or from his first taste of Daenerys Targaryen.


Considering he was still weightless and turning, but without the nausea of a hangover, it had to be her.


Fuck, he was so done for. The previous night had been the final crack that toppled the wall, and that was before he’d even kissed her. No, that decision had been made the moment his fingers had curled around that shot glass to follow the rules she’d sternly laid out. Now he stood in the rubble of what had been his rules, the dirt and debris of the safety net he’d been hiding behind, finally out in the open and willing to see the consequences.


And all because he couldn’t stand the thought of her not understanding how godsdamned wonderful she was— how she made him want to climb out of the icy cage that he’d been stuck in, just to be around her and soak up that endless fire she provided.


The breathing against his skin broke, breath catching, her palm sliding down his abdomen— in hindsight, he should have kept his shirt on— as she shifted, and he caught her hand carefully, pressed a soft kiss to the inside of her wrist in apology, already hard and aching for her.


For a moment he let himself fantasize about rolling her onto her back and waking her up in other pleasurable manners, before getting lost inside of her, but it wasn’t right yet. He wanted her, fuck, he wanted her, jaw clenching with effort as he carefully slipped free of the tangle of her limbs, but he needed to make sure she had seen all of him first— all the broken bits and not just the man keeping her safe.


Rolling onto his side, a cautious arm’s length away he watched her eyelids flutter, lashes dark against her cheek, his heart giving a resounding thump to remind him it still worked as her mouth rounded with the displeasure of waking up. A whine came from that back of her throat, her small hand moving heavily up to cover her eyes as she groaned at the sharpness of the light.


“Oh gods, we drank that whole bottle, didn’t we?”


“Technically, you had a head start.”


Her hand froze, the blue of her eyes peeking from between her fingers, surprise not quite muffled. “Jon?”


“Aye.” He chuckled and caught her hand. “Who did you think I was?”


There was no answer as she buried her face in his pillow, a growing nervousness that maybe he’d overstepped or fuck, even misread the situation, drunken choices mistaken for sober ones, before she lifted her head, pushing the knotted mess of silver from her vision. “I didn’t realize I was in your room. I should have known, the pillows smell like you.”

~*~*~

Ok fam— here’s the plan. If the 8.05 sucks, we’re posting on Sunday night as soon as we stop crying. If the ep is good, we’ll post Monday morning in celebration. Either way, know this— @notpmahlem and I are not going anywhere. The beauty of Modern AU is that these characters are as much ours as they are anyone else’s and NO ONE is taking that away from us.

We gotchu, fam. We gotchu. &hearts to all.


(Also, Mel is super talented— look at that moodboard! 😍)

A whine came from that back of her throat, her small hand moving heavily up to cover her eyes as she groaned at the sharpness of the light.


“Oh gods, we drank that whole bottle, didn’t we?”


“Technically, you had a head start.”


Her hand froze, the blue of her eyes peeking from between her fingers, surprise not quite muffled. “Jon?”


“Aye.” He chuckled and caught her hand. “Who did you think I was?”


There was no answer as she buried her face in his pillow, a growing nervousness that maybe he’d overstepped or fuck, even misread the situation, drunken choices mistaken for sober ones, before she lifted her head, pushing the knotted mess of silver from her vision. “I didn’t realize I was in your room. I should have known, the pillows smell like you.”

~*~*~

Ok fam— here’s the plan. If the 8.05 sucks, we’re posting on Sunday night as soon as we stop crying. If the ep is good, we’ll post Monday morning in celebration. Either way, know this— @notpmahlem and I are not going anywhere. The beauty of Modern AU is that these characters are as much ours as they are anyone else’s and NO ONE is taking that away from us.

We gotchu, fam. We gotchu. &hearts to all.


(Also, Mel is super talented— look at that moodboard! 😍)

summary: LOOK AT THIS, JONSA FAM IF YOU ADD SOME LIGHT TO THE SCENES OF THE FEAST YOU KNOW, THE SCENES IN WHICH SANSA’S ROMANTIC FEELINGS...
body:
LOOK AT THIS, JONSA FAM

IF YOU ADD SOME LIGHT TO THE SCENES OF THE FEAST

YOU KNOW, THE SCENES IN WHICH SANSA’S ROMANTIC FEELINGS FOR JON BECOME UNDENIABLY, FOREVER CANON

YOU SEE THAT SHE IS WEARING THE DRESS

THAT SHE WEARS ON THE POSTER FOR SEASON 8.

So basically, the scene that makes Jonsa canon (at least from Sansa’s side) gives us this photo of Sansa on the Iron Throne.

This is the real thing, people. Sansa fighting for Jon’s claim on the Iron Throne is linked to her romantic feelings for him. And her becoming Queen (in the North or of Westeros in general) is linked to these feelings. 

This is no coincidence. They could have chosen any other dress. A fitting choice could have been Sansa’s armor-like dress, which is both beautiful and very telling of her feelings and of her fight this season. But instead, they went with this dress that seems to bear no particular meaning about Sansa’s state of mind.

This choice is not random. Not when other posters have hidden meanings. Jon’s show him in the same position than his (adoptive) father, therefore linking him to his Stark legacy rather than to the Targaryen family, and connecting his arc to the weight of politics and of bearing the future of a kingdom on his shoulders. Daenerys wears red gloves that metaphorically echoes the hands covered with blood, among many other meanings. Cersei wears the dress she wears when she kills Missandei, when she learns that Rhaegal is dead and when she makes the smallfolk enter the Red Keep: this is symbolic of her victory over Daenerys (for now. It might take other meanings later). Jaime wears his travelling clothes, linking him to his two most important moments in the season: coming to Winterfell to keep his oath and fight (choosing Brienne), and coming back to Cersei to fulfill their destinies. Theon’s armor is broken at the point where the Night King pierced his armor to kill him, echoing his death and his recovered identity. And so on and so forth. 

So this choice for Sansa, instead of other dresses that might better reflect her objectives this season, indicates that there is more here than meets the eye, and that the moments when she wears this dress must be important. 

Some people have argued that this dress echoes her Tully ancestry, meaning that she could have the Riverlands backing her against Daenerys, and I agree with this theory. However, I also think that the context in which Sansa is seen wearing this dress is paramount to understand her arc and this season in general, for it is a clue to what is going on. 

So the fact that this dress is connected with the very scenes when we get to see Sansa’s real feelings for Jon (and not her fight with Daenerys, for example) tells us that her feelings for Jon are primordial to the season, but also, most importantly, to the future of the realm and to the Iron Throne. 

(After all, Sansa revealed Jon’s identity to Tyrion because of her feelings, as her scene with Tyrion shows explicitly…)
